parameterized_text: Task: In the course "[[Course]]" view the page titled "[[Page]]" by navigating to the Pages Index and selecting the page from the list. Return the contents of the page body.

instances.instance_text: Task: In the course "Astrobiology and Planetary Habitability 312" view the page titled "Exoplanet Atmospheres and Habitability" by navigating to the Pages Index and selecting the page from the list. Return the contents of the page body.

answer_key.Text: Exoplanet atmospheres are a primary determinant of planetary habitability because they control surface temperature, shield against harmful radiation, and mediate volatile cycles. Observational techniques such as transit and eclipse spectroscopy, direct imaging, and phase curve analysis provide constraints on molecular composition, thermal profiles, and cloud properties. Important physical and chemical processes include atmospheric escape driven by stellar irradiation, photochemistry that can create or destroy potential biosignatures, and radiative transfer that governs greenhouse warming. Candidate biosignature gases like water vapor, oxygen, ozone, methane, and carbon dioxide must be interpreted with care to avoid abiotic false positives caused by geophysical or stellar effects. Modeling tools range from one dimensional radiative convective calculations to three dimensional general circulation models, each with trade offs in complexity and computational cost. This page summarizes diagnostic observables, best practice approaches for atmospheric retrievals, common pitfalls in habitability inference, and recent mission capabilities relevant to the field. Students will find recommended readings, data sets for hands on practice, and questions for critical evaluation of current claims about habitable worlds. Active participation in data interpretation exercises is encouraged to develop skills in uncertainty quantification and hypothesis testing

parameterized_text: Task: Leave the group "[[Group]]" in the course "[[Course]]" using the People page in Canvas.

instances.instance_text: Task: Leave the group "Extremophile Squad" in the course "Astrobiology and Planetary Habitability 312" using the People page in Canvas.

parameterized_text: Task: In your "[[Course]]" course, change your discussion settings so that you must manually mark discussion replies as read.

instances.instance_text: Task: In your "Astrobiology and Planetary Habitability 312" course, change your discussion settings so that you must manually mark discussion replies as read.

parameterized_text: Task: In the course "[[Course]]" view all available groups, and join the self sign-up group named "[[Group]]"

instances.instance_text: Task: In the course "Astrobiology and Planetary Habitability 312" view all available groups, and join the self sign-up group named "Exoplanet Explorers"

parameterized_text: Task: Take the "[[Quiz]]" quiz in the "[[Course]]" course, answer all questions, and submit the quiz.

instances.instance_text: Task: Take the "Biosignatures in Planetary Spectra" quiz in the "Astrobiology and Planetary Habitability 312" course, answer all questions, and submit the quiz.

parameterized_text: Task: In the course "[[Course]]" find the announcement titled "[[Announcement]]" in your Course Activity Stream and remove this notification from your activity stream.

instances.instance_text: Task: In the course "Astrobiology and Planetary Habitability 312" find the announcement titled "Midterm review session materials uploaded" in your Course Activity Stream and remove this notification from your activity stream.

parameterized_text: Task: In the course "[[Course]]" view all modules, expand the module titled [[Module]]" and identify the due date for the assignment named "[[Assignment]]."

instances.instance_text: Task: In the course "Astrobiology and Planetary Habitability 312" view all modules, expand the module titled Astrobiology 312 Week 2 Stellar and Atmospheric Processes" and identify the due date for the assignment named "Stellar Radiation and Atmospheric Escape."

mapping.Module: Astrobiology 312 Week 2 Stellar and Atmospheric Processes

parameterized_text: Task: View your instructor's comments on the "[[Quiz]]" quiz in the "[[Course]]" course and add a comment saying "Thank you for the feedback!" to your quiz submission.

instances.instance_text: Task: View your instructor's comments on the "Planetary Atmospheres and Climate" quiz in the "Astrobiology and Planetary Habitability 312" course and add a comment saying "Thank you for the feedback!" to your quiz submission.

parameterized_text: Task: Resume the "[[Quiz]]" in the "[[Course]]" course that you previously started but did not finish.

instances.instance_text: Task: Resume the "Origins of Life on Earth" in the "Astrobiology and Planetary Habitability 312" course that you previously started but did not finish.

parameterized_text: Task: Submit the "[[Survey]]" survey in the "[[Course]]" course by answering all questions and submitting your responses.

instances.instance_text: Task: Submit the "Hydrothermal Systems and Life" survey in the "Astrobiology and Planetary Habitability 312" course by answering all questions and submitting your responses.

parameterized_text: Task: View the results of your second attempt on the "[[Quiz]]" in the "[[Course]]" course, and report the time it took in minutes to complete that attempt as displayed in the Last Attempt Details section.

instances.instance_text: Task: View the results of your second attempt on the "Exoplanet Detection Methods" in the "Astrobiology and Planetary Habitability 312" course, and report the time it took in minutes to complete that attempt as displayed in the Last Attempt Details section.

parameterized_text: Task: View the feedback you received from [[User]] for the "[[Discussion]]" peer-reviewed discussion by accessing the Feedback tray from the Course Grades page in your "[[Course]]" course. What was the comment that [[User]] left for your submission?

instances.instance_text: Task: View the feedback you received from Abigail Studentson for the "Mission Design for Life Detection" peer-reviewed discussion by accessing the Feedback tray from the Course Grades page in your "Astrobiology and Planetary Habitability 312" course. What was the comment that Abigail Studentson left for your submission?

answer_key.Text: Nice concept I would like to see more on contamination control and detection thresholds

parameterized_text: Task: In the course "[[Course]]" view your Learning Mastery grades for the outcome group "[[Course]]" expand the group to see all outcomes, and report the number of mastered outcomes.

instances.instance_text: Task: In the course "Astrobiology and Planetary Habitability 312" view your Learning Mastery grades for the outcome group "Astrobiology and Planetary Habitability 312" expand the group to see all outcomes, and report the number of mastered outcomes.

parameterized_text: Task: In the "[[Course]]" course, navigate to the "[[Module]]" module, click the "Choose Assignment Group" link, and select the assignment titled "[[Assignment]]" by clicking the Select button.

instances.instance_text: Task: In the "Astrobiology and Planetary Habitability 312" course, navigate to the "Special Module A" module, click the "Choose Assignment Group" link, and select the assignment titled "Methane on Mars and Other Worlds" by clicking the Select button.
